natural problem: $P(x)$ is a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x-13$ the remainder is $19$, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x+17$ the remainder is $-11$. What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x-13)(x+17)$?
natural solution: Since we are dividing by a quadratic, the remainder will have degree less than 2.
So the remainder $r(x)=ax+b$ for some constants $a$ and $b$.

We have, $$P(x) = (x-13)(x+17)Q(x) +ax+b$$where $Q(x)$ is the quotient of the division. Then, using the Remainder Theorem, $$\begin{aligned} P(13) &= 13a+b = 19 \\ P(-17) &= -17a+b = -11 \end{aligned}$$.
Solving this system of equations gives us $a=1$ and $b=6$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and Q1 Q2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and R1 R2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. P x mod (x - 13) = R1 x"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. R1 x = 19"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. P x mod (x + 17) = R2 x"
and h3 : "\<forall>x. R2 x = -11"
shows  "\<forall>x. P x mod ((x - 13) * (x + 17)) = x + 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 $P(x)$ is a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x-13$ the remainder is $19$, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x+17$ the remainder is $-11$. What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x-13)(x+17)$? The final Answer is x+6
 ### Proof
 Since we are dividing by a quadratic, the remainder will have degree less than 2.
 So the remainder $r(x)=ax+b$ for some constants $a$ and $b$.
 We have, $$P(x) = (x-13)(x+17)Q(x) +ax+b$$where $Q(x)$ is the quotient of the division. Then, using the Remainder Theorem, $$\begin{aligned} P(13) &= 13a+b = 19 \\ P(-17) &= -17a+b = -11 \end{aligned}$$.
 Solving this system of equations gives us $a=1$ and $b=6$.
 So the remainder is $\boxed{x+6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and Q1 Q2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and R1 R2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. P x mod (x - 13) = R1 x"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. R1 x = 19"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. P x mod (x + 17) = R2 x"
and h3 : "\<forall>x. R2 x = -11"
shows  "\<forall>x. P x mod ((x - 13) * (x + 17)) = x + 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given two equations, the first one being the remainder of function $P(x)$ when divided by $(x - 13)$ is always $19$ and the second one being the remainder of function $P(x)$ when divided by $(x + 17)$ is always $-11$. Find the remainder of function $P(x)$ when divided by the product of $(x - 13)$ and $(x + 17)$. The final answer is $x + 6$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R S :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x - 13) = 19"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x + 17) = -11"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 13) * Q x + 19"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x + 17) * R x - 11"
and h4 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 13) * (x + 17) * S x + R x"
shows  "R x = x + 6"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 $P(x)$ is a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x-13$ the remainder is $19$, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x+17$ the remainder is $-11$. What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x-13)(x+17)$? The final Answer is x+6
 ### Proof
 Since we are dividing by a quadratic, the remainder will have degree less than 2.
 So the remainder $r(x)=ax+b$ for some constants $a$ and $b$.
 We have, $$P(x) = (x-13)(x+17)Q(x) +ax+b$$where $Q(x)$ is the quotient of the division. Then, using the Remainder Theorem, $$\begin{aligned} P(13) &= 13a+b = 19 \\ P(-17) &= -17a+b = -11 \end{aligned}$$.
 Solving this system of equations gives us $a=1$ and $b=6$.
 So the remainder is $\boxed{x+6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R S :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x - 13) = 19"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x + 17) = -11"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 13) * Q x + 19"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x + 17) * R x - 11"
and h4 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 13) * (x + 17) * S x + R x"
shows  "R x = x + 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Consider a function P(x) such that the remainder when P(x) is divided by (x - 13) is 19, and the remainder when P(x) is divided by (x + 17) is -11. Moreover, P(x) can be written in three different ways: as (x - 13) times some function Q(x) plus 19, as (x + 17) times some function R(x) minus 11, and as the product of (x - 13), (x + 17), and some function S(x), plus the value of R(x). Find the function R(x). The final answer is R(x) = x + 6.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and x :: real
assumes h0 : "\<exists> Q R. (\<forall>x. P x = (x - 13) * Q x + 19) \<and> (\<forall>x. P x = (x + 17) * R x - 11)"
shows  "\<exists> Q. \<forall>x. P x = (x - 13) * (x + 17) * Q x + x + 6"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 $P(x)$ is a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x-13$ the remainder is $19$, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x+17$ the remainder is $-11$. What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x-13)(x+17)$? The final Answer is x+6
 ### Proof
 Since we are dividing by a quadratic, the remainder will have degree less than 2.
 So the remainder $r(x)=ax+b$ for some constants $a$ and $b$.
 We have, $$P(x) = (x-13)(x+17)Q(x) +ax+b$$where $Q(x)$ is the quotient of the division. Then, using the Remainder Theorem, $$\begin{aligned} P(13) &= 13a+b = 19 \\ P(-17) &= -17a+b = -11 \end{aligned}$$.
 Solving this system of equations gives us $a=1$ and $b=6$.
 So the remainder is $\boxed{x+6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and x :: real
assumes h0 : "\<exists> Q R. (\<forall>x. P x = (x - 13) * Q x + 19) \<and> (\<forall>x. P x = (x + 17) * R x - 11)"
shows  "\<exists> Q. \<forall>x. P x = (x - 13) * (x + 17) * Q x + x + 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a function $P(x)$ that can be expressed in the form $(x - 13)Q(x) + 19$ or $(x + 17)R(x) - 11$ for all $x$, show that $P(x)$ can also be expressed in the form $(x - 13)(x + 17)Q(x) + x + 6$ for all $x$ for some function $Q(x)$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. \<exists> Q1 R1. P x = (x - 13) * Q1 x + 19"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. \<exists> Q2 R2. P x = (x + 17) * Q2 x - 11"
shows  "\<exists> Q R. P x = (x - 13) * (x + 17) * Q x + R x \<and> R x = x + 6"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 $P(x)$ is a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x-13$ the remainder is $19$, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x+17$ the remainder is $-11$. What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x-13)(x+17)$? The final Answer is x+6
 ### Proof

 Solving this system of equations gives us $a=1$ and $b=6$.
 So the remainder is $\boxed{x+6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. \<exists> Q1 R1. P x = (x - 13) * Q1 x + 19"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. \<exists> Q2 R2. P x = (x + 17) * Q2 x - 11"
shows  "\<exists> Q R. P x = (x - 13) * (x + 17) * Q x + R x \<and> R x = x + 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given a real number $x$ and a function $P(x)$ such that $P(x)$ can be expressed as $(x - 13)Q1(x) + 19$ for some function $Q1(x)$ and as $(x + 17)Q2(x) - 11$ for some function $Q2(x)$, find functions $Q(x)$ and $R(x)$ such that $P(x) = (x - 13)(x + 17)Q(x) + R(x)$ and $R(x) = x + 6$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and x :: real
assumes h0 : "\<exists> Q1 Q2 R1 R2. (\<forall>x. P x = Q1 x * (x - 13) + 19) \<and> (\<forall>x. P x = Q2 x * (x + 17) - 11)"
shows  "\<exists> Q R. \<forall>x. P x = Q x * (x - 13) * (x + 17) + R x \<and> R x = x + 6"

(* ### Problem
 $P(x)$ is a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x-13$ the remainder is $19$, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x+17$ the remainder is $-11$. What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x-13)(x+17)$? The final Answer is x+6

 Solving this system of equations gives us $a=1$ and $b=6$.
 So the remainder is $\boxed{x+6}$.

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and x :: real
assumes h0 : "\<exists> Q1 Q2 R1 R2. (\<forall>x. P x = Q1 x * (x - 13) + 19) \<and> (\<forall>x. P x = Q2 x * (x + 17) - 11)"
shows  "\<exists> Q R. \<forall>x. P x = Q x * (x - 13) * (x + 17) + R x \<and> R x = x + 6"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find functions Q and R such that for all real numbers x, the function P can be expressed as P(x) = Q(x) * (x - 13) * (x + 17) + R(x) where R(x) = x + 6, given that there exist functions Q1, Q2, R1, and R2 such that for all real numbers x, P can be expressed as P(x) = Q1(x) * (x - 13) + 19 and P(x) = Q2(x) * (x + 17) - 11.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<exists> q1. \<forall> x. P x = (x - 13) * q1 x + 19"
and h1 : "\<exists> q2. \<forall> x. P x = (x + 17) * q2 x - 11"
shows  "\<exists> q3. \<forall> x. P x = (x - 13) * (x + 17) * q3 x + x + 6"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 $P(x)$ is a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x-13$ the remainder is $19$, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x+17$ the remainder is $-11$. What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x-13)(x+17)$? The final Answer is x+6

 Solving this system of equations gives us $a=1$ and $b=6$.
 So the remainder is $\boxed{x+6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<exists> q1. \<forall> x. P x = (x - 13) * q1 x + 19"
and h1 : "\<exists> q2. \<forall> x. P x = (x + 17) * q2 x - 11"
shows  "\<exists> q3. \<forall> x. P x = (x - 13) * (x + 17) * q3 x + x + 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem:
Find a function $P(x)$ that can be expressed in three different forms:

1) $P(x) = (x - 13)q_1(x) + 19$ for some function $q_1(x)$,
2) $P(x) = (x + 17)q_2(x) - 11$ for some function $q_2(x)$,

And it is needed to show that there exists a function $q_3(x)$ such that

3) $P(x) = (x - 13)(x + 17)q_3(x) + x + 6$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x - 13) = 19"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x + 17) = -11"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x mod ((x - 13) * (x + 17)) = x + 6"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 $P(x)$ is a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x-13$ the remainder is $19$, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x+17$ the remainder is $-11$. What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x-13)(x+17)$? The final Answer is x+6
 ### Proof
 Since we are dividing by a quadratic, the remainder will have degree less than 2.
 So the remainder $r(x)=ax+b$ for some constants $a$ and $b$.

 Solving this system of equations gives us $a=1$ and $b=6$.
 So the remainder is $\boxed{x+6}$.

theorem
fixes x P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x - 13) = 19"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x + 17) = -11"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x mod ((x - 13) * (x + 17)) = x + 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: For a real number x, find a function P such that the remainder when P(x) is divided by (x - 13) is 19, and the remainder when P(x) is divided by (x + 17) is -11. Show that the remainder when P(x) is divided by ((x - 13) * (x + 17)) is x + 6.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr n + a"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 13"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. R x = x + 17"
and h3 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h4 : "P x dvd R x"
and h5 : "\<forall> x. Q x = P x * (x - 13) + 19"
and h6 : "\<forall> x. R x = P x * (x + 17) - 11"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 13) * (x + 17) * (x + 6)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 $P(x)$ is a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x-13$ the remainder is $19$, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x+17$ the remainder is $-11$. What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x-13)(x+17)$? The final Answer is x+6
 ### Proof
 Since we are dividing by a quadratic, the remainder will have degree less than 2.
 So the remainder $r(x)=ax+b$ for some constants $a$ and $b$.
 We have, $$P(x) = (x-13)(x+17)Q(x) +ax+b$$where $Q(x)$ is the quotient of the division. Then, using the Remainder Theorem, $$\begin{aligned} P(13) &= 13a+b = 19 \\ P(-17) &= -17a+b = -11 \end{aligned}$$.
 Solving this system of equations gives us $a=1$ and $b=6$.
 So the remainder is $\boxed{x+6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr n + a"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x - 13"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. R x = x + 17"
and h3 : "P x dvd Q x"
and h4 : "P x dvd R x"
and h5 : "\<forall> x. Q x = P x * (x - 13) + 19"
and h6 : "\<forall> x. R x = P x * (x + 17) - 11"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 13) * (x + 17) * (x + 6)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Let $P(x) = x^n + a$, $Q(x) = x - 13$, and $R(x) = x + 17$. If $P(x)$ divides $Q(x)$ and $R(x)$, and $Q(x)$ can be expressed as $P(x) * (x - 13) + 19$ and $R(x)$ can be expressed as $P(x) * (x + 17) - 11$, prove that for all $x$, $P(x) = (x - 13) * (x + 17) * (x + 6)$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x - 13) = 19"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x + 17) = -11"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 13) * (x + 17) * R x + x + 6"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x mod ((x - 13) * (x + 17)) = x + 6"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 $P(x)$ is a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x-13$ the remainder is $19$, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x+17$ the remainder is $-11$. What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x-13)(x+17)$? The final Answer is x+6
 ### Proof
 Since we are dividing by a quadratic, the remainder will have degree less than 2.
 So the remainder $r(x)=ax+b$ for some constants $a$ and $b$.
 We have, $$P(x) = (x-13)(x+17)Q(x) +ax+b$$where $Q(x)$ is the quotient of the division. Then, using the Remainder Theorem, $$\begin{aligned} P(13) &= 13a+b = 19 \\ P(-17) &= -17a+b = -11 \end{aligned}$$.
 Solving this system of equations gives us $a=1$ and $b=6$.
 So the remainder is $\boxed{x+6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x - 13) = 19"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x + 17) = -11"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 13) * (x + 17) * R x + x + 6"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x mod ((x - 13) * (x + 17)) = x + 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given the function P(x), if P(x) modulo (x - 13) equals 19 and P(x) modulo (x + 17) equals -11 and P(x) equals (x - 13) times (x + 17) times R(x) plus x plus 6, then prove that for all x, P(x) modulo the product of (x - 13) and (x + 17) equals x plus 6.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x - 13) = 19"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x + 17) = -11"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 13) * (x + 17) * R x"
shows  "R x = x + 6"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 $P(x)$ is a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x-13$ the remainder is $19$, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x+17$ the remainder is $-11$. What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x-13)(x+17)$? The final Answer is x+6
 ### Proof
 Since we are dividing by a quadratic, the remainder will have degree less than 2.
 So the remainder $r(x)=ax+b$ for some constants $a$ and $b$.
 We have, $$P(x) = (x-13)(x+17)Q(x) +ax+b$$where $Q(x)$ is the quotient of the division. Then, using the Remainder Theorem, $$\begin{aligned} P(13) &= 13a+b = 19 \\ P(-17) &= -17a+b = -11 \end{aligned}$$.
 Solving this system of equations gives us $a=1$ and $b=6$.
 So the remainder is $\boxed{x+6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x - 13) = 19"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x + 17) = -11"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 13) * (x + 17) * R x"
shows  "R x = x + 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find a function R(x) such that for every real number x, P(x) is equal to the product of (x - 13), (x + 17), and R(x), where P(x) modulo (x - 13) equals to 19 and P(x) modulo (x + 17) equals to -11. The final answer is R(x) = x + 6.
